user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarLock_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarLock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarLock_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the function modify the function parameter itself. The following were examined and found safe with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8:

- The use of *token in the macro invocation impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token); only dereferences the pointer to obtain the object for indexing; it does not assign to or otherwise modify the token pointer parameter.
- The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) expands to (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))]) which becomes &tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(*token))] when invoked. This takes the address of the object referred to by token (effectively token) and does not modify the pointer parameter or the object.
- There are no assignments to token, no increments/decrements, and token is not passed to any function in a way that would modify the pointer itself. The only other operations access impl and impl->mut; these do not modify the parameter.

Given the above, there are no fragments that appear to violate the rule (i.e., no modifications of the pointer parameter or of the pointed-to object via a non-allowed mechanism).
